 Our discussion was about the US Constitution, specifically the Full Faith clause. State courts can render opinions, but it's the US Supreme Court that has the real say. Until the SC renders an opinion the issue is still up in the air, anything a state court says is just background. Perhaps not utterly irrelevant, but by no means definitive. So if Lanham v. Lanham was just Wisconsin saying they could ignore another state's marriage, and the case never made it to the Supreme Court, then that case didn't really test the Full Faith clause in a way that would matter in this discussion.
